title: Kick It Out had governance failures, Charity Commission report finds
text:
Football’s equality charity, Kick It Out, was found to have governance failures after concerns were raised last year about safeguarding, bullying and harassment.

The conclusions of a regulatory compliance case, commissioned by the Charity Commission, have been released and found that poor communication among senior management and trustees led to the slow sharing of information of a serious incident involving a staff member.

The Charity Commission was initially contacted in September 2018 by people associated with Kick It Out and the organisation then informed the commission about a report of an alleged sexual assault in 2017. Interviews were held and this information helped set the terms of reference for a QC-led review of the charity.

The commission found that the governance failures did not contribute to the occurrence of the serious incident or how the victim was supported but the report did identify a number of failings. These included poor communication and a lack of training in key areas such as governance and staff welfare. Many staff felt they were not managed well by the senior management team, with some feeling overworked and inadequately supported.

A series of recommendations have been made and Kick It Out now has a new chair - Sanjay Bhandari - and three other new trustees in post.

“The trustees of Kick It Out should have made protecting those who came into contact with their charity from harm a governance priority,” said Tracy Howarth, the Charity Commission’s head of regulatory compliance.
